Hi Joel,

On 9 April 2011 04:06, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:
> Certainly a lone single-celled organism would not fare well in a niche requiring human-level
> intelligence, because such a niche does benefit from multi-cellularity, having a brain, etc.
> However, us multi-cellular organisms, by virtue of having to make multiple cells, are less
> efficient replicators, which is the biological benchmark test.

Noting "efficient replicators, which is the biological benchmark test"... and...

> The argument is not that single-celled organisms can do everything that a human can do
> better, just that bacteria are *quantatively* better at the one measure central to evolution
> (and which is traditionally abstracted as a fitness function in EC): How well do you replicate
> (meet the objective)?

Please correct me if I'm wrong but I suspect you are building from an
invalid logical conclusion. You seem to be equating scale of
reproduction (e.g. zillions of bacteria) with fitness, hence the
conclusion that bacteria are fitter than whales on the only metric
that matters - reproduction.

The central issue here is how we define fitness. I think the the root
of your logical error is in considering fitness as a simple metric
where we can take any two organisms/agents and state that one is
fitter than the other based on reproductive efficiency and overall
population size. I believe this view of fitness as a simple linear
metric is wrong and thus any conclusions we build from this assumption
are on shaky ground.

A critical aspect of natural evolution is variation and adaptability.
If you occupy some minority niche then there's a chance that you're
offspring will become more numerous in future because, e.g. there's
another much larger niche that leads on from there that simpler
species can't get too (human ancestors fit this pattern) or some
change in environment causes previously dominant species to die out or
become the minority and/or your niche becomes much larger/widespread.
You could argue that a changing environment (e.g. natural disaster or
oxygenation of the atmosphere) represent different fitness functions,
species A was optimal at time t, species B was optimal at time t+1M
years. But even that still leaves the first argument that minority
niches may lead to large uncolonised environments.

So my argument in a nutshell - reproductive efficiency != fitness.
Reproduction is a /pre-requisite/ to evolutionary fitness (without it
you're a non-starter) but it should not be considered a simple linear
metric of fitness even within the context of a static fitness
function/landscape. If the landscape is complex then minority
strategies may lead to dominant strategies in the future and you can't
know which strategies today will lead to the successful ones in the
future. This is not entirely the same as novelty search but it can be
depending on what the novelty metric is. So I would say that novelty
search can be considered a means of adding complexity to the simple
fitness landscapes defined by narrow objective functions (because
selecting based on novelty or a mix of novelty and fitness defines a
fitness landscape distinct from the simple target objective - there is
still an objective function, but one that is a modified version of the
primary objective).

I was going to respond to some of your other points but I'll leave it
there as I believe the above focuses on the essential underlying
issue(s).

Colin.
